   perfusion to more ventilated areas while on CVVH break today
   - restart CVVHDF once access obtained to remove volume.  Respiratory
   status will likely benefit from volume removal.
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  On vasopressin and levophed.
   Intermittently has required phenylephrine to maintain MAPs >60.
   Continues to spike low grade temps, most likely source at this point is
   line infection.  On zosyn for concern for cholangitis given
   infected-appearing bile by ERCP.  Re-started Vanc [**9-28**] for suspected
   line infection, although vanc trough was therapeutic even after vanc
   was originally d/c
   - re-site HD and subclavian lines by IR today.  Replace A-line once
   back from IR.  Culture all tips.
   - foley changed yesterday
   - continue vanc and zosyn for now.
   - f/u culture data.
   - continue vasopressin.  levophed and phenylephrine PRN for MAPs < 60.
   Goal MAP > 65.  Will likely require some pressure support for IR
   procedure today.
   - trend fever curve and WBC
   .
   # Acute renal failure:  BUN/Cr/K/PO4 up off CVVH.  Likely ATN highest
   on differential at this point. Started CVVH Monday afternoon [**9-25**];
   patient tolerating well.  D/c
d [**9-27**] overnight for line kinking and
   pustular drainage around line.
   - restart CVVHDF after access today
   - Renal following

   stopped [**9-25**]
   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot
   take po
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to
   give maintenance dose through IV (200 mg/day)
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase.   LFTs trending down
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs

   - trophic feeds started [**9-28**], NPO for procedure [**9-29**], will re-start
   and advance as tolerated
   - re-start TPN once access achieved after IR procedure for now with
   plan to bridge to full tube feeds
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now given changes in TPN/tube feeds.
   - Trial of trophic tube feeds today and attempt to wean down insulin
   gtt
   - will calculate 24 hour insulin needs once on stable tube feeds and
   transition to long-acting regimen
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31 (from 52 at OSH when

   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.

His neck is supple, but jugular venous distention (JVD) is difficult to assess due to neck edema. His lung examination reveals bilateral anterior lung fields with improved breath sounds and air movement bilaterally. Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with severe gallstone pancreatitis and multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS). The patient has several ongoing medical complications, including respiratory failure/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute renal failure (ARF), hypotension, fever, leukocytosis, hyperglycemia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and possible Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection.

The patient's primary issues remain severe gallstone pancreatitis, respiratory failure/ARDS, hypotension, fever, leukocytosis, ARF, hyperglycemia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and poor prognosis. The patient is critically ill with multiorgan failure and has a high likelihood of sepsis, as indicated by the presence of fever and rising white blood cell count. 

The patient has been treated for an infection in the hemodialysis (HD) line, and the line has been removed due to pus at the entry site. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, making C. diff infection a concern. 

The patient's left and alkaline phosphatase levels are decreasing, and recent right upper quadrant (RUQ) ultrasound was unimpressive. Chest X-rays have not revealed any new findings, and there is no change in airway secretions or obvious new infiltrate.

The patient remains very tenuous from a respiratory standpoint in the setting

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with severe gallstone pancreatitis and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MOSD). He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient is also experiencing hypotension, fever, acute kidney injury (ARF), hyperglycemia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and rising white blood cell count.

The patient's condition remains tenuous, and he is at high risk for infection and recurrent sepsis. He is receiving multiple vasopressors to maintain blood pressure, and his oxygen requirements are gradually being weaned off. The patient's pancreatic and liver enzymes are decreasing, but he continues to have poor respiratory compliance and elevated platelet pressures.

There are concerns about possible linen infection or sepsis, as pus is noted at the site of the hemodialysis line. The patient's central venous catheter (CVC) tip culture is positive for yeast, indicating a possible line infection. The plan is to remove the current HD line and send the tip for culture. An interventional radiology (IR) procedure will be performed to change the HD line and resite the CVL. 

The patient's abdominal distention may contribute to his high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) needs. His blood pressure and lactate levels are being monitored closely, and he is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics

   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio 96.
   Ventilation per ARDS protocol with goal minimize TV and PEEP to keep
   plateau pressures low, goal < 40.  Has tolerated weaning to TV 370.
   S/P IR procedure yesterday likely derecruited a lot of lung as patient
   is on higher FiO2 requirements and higher PEEP. Patient slowly
   improving, but still on very high settings to maintain appropriate
   oxygen levels.
   - Continue to manage per ARDS net, goal PaO2 > 60, plateau pressures <
   40 for now given increased abdominal pressure and PEEP requirement.
   - Decrease FiO2 to 80% and check ABG.
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas while on CVVH break today
   - restart CVVHDF once access obtained to remove volume.  Respiratory
   status will likely benefit from volume removal.
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  On vasopressin and levophed to maintain
   appropriate MAPs. Continues to spike low grade temps with increasing
   WBC. Most likely source at this point is line infection, although
   removal of lines and treatment has not changed patient
s clinical
   status.  Was on Zosyn for x days, but overnight changed to meropenem
   for broader coverage.  Re-started Vanc [**9-28**] for suspected line
   infection. Other sources: VAP (unable to see on CXR in setting of
   ARDS); Sinusitis: but patient is being treated for this and has had no
   more discharge from his nares. Intra-abdominal is unlikely as RUQ u/s
   negative and enzymes are all trending down. C. diff possibility
   (previous was negative) possible DVT, but unlikely to cause significant
   wbc.
   - if patient
s respiratory status improves consider CT of
   abdomen/chest.
   - continue vanc and meropenem (day 1: [**2169-9-29**]) for now.  (Vanc Trough
   22.2 this AM)
   - Vanc trough this PM before dosage: should dose all Abx with a CrCl of
   < 30 while on CVVH per Renal
   - Will double cover for pseudomonas with Cipro (day 1: [**2169-9-30**])
   - f/u culture data.
   - Check C. diff today
   - Lactate pending
   - continue vasopressin.  levophed for MAPs < 65.  Wean down as
   tolerated
   - trend fever curve and WBC
   - foley changed [**9-28**]); New lines placed [**2169-9-29**]
   - If still unable to find source, consider LENI
s to rule out DVT.
   .
   # Acute renal failure:  BUN/Cr/K/PO4 up off CVVH.  Likely ATN highest
   on differential at this point. Started CVVH Monday afternoon [**9-25**];
   patient tolerating well.  D/c
d [**9-27**] overnight for line kinking and

   patient may be a bit intravascularly depleted and the HD catheter is

   - Ensure technical difficulties are addressed and fixed so CVVH can

s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to acute renal failure. The patient has multiple medical complications including hypotension, atrial fibrillation, anemia, thrombocytopenia, hyperglycemia, and potential infections such as line infection, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and sinusitis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's low PaO2/FiO2 ratio indicates severe hypoxemia, which can lead to further respiratory distress and potentially ventilator-associated lung injury.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's elevated BUN, creatinine, and potassium levels suggest impaired kidney function, which may progress to end-stage renal disease if not managed appropriately.
3. Septic shock: The patient's persistent fever, tachycardia, hypotension, and elevated white blood cell count indicate ongoing infection and sepsis. This can lead to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and potentially death if not promptly treated.
4. Line infection: The presence of pus around the femoral line and elevated white blood cell count suggests a possible line infection, which can be a source of bloodstream infection and sepsis.

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of HTN and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure currently
   on CVVH.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio 99.
   Ventilation per ARDS protocol with goal minimize TV and PEEP to keep
   plateau pressures low, goal < 40.  Has tolerated weaning to TV 370,
   PEEP 22, FiO2 50% although with desaturations on
   movement/rotation/stimulation to 80s requiring transient increase in
   FiO2.  Sedation increased due to overbreathing on vent and need to
   ventilate at lower TVs, which were not tolerated on decreased sedation.
   - Continue to manage per ARDS net, goal PaO2 > 60, plateau pressures <
   40 for now given increased abdominal pressure and PEEP requirement.
   - will likely need increased FiO2/PEEP for IR procedure today.
   Re-check gas once back from IR and continue to manage vent settings
   according to ARDS net goals.
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas while on CVVH break today
   - restart CVVHDF once access obtained to remove volume.  Respiratory
   status will likely benefit from volume removal.
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  On vasopressin and levophed.
   Intermittently has required phenylephrine to maintain MAPs >60.
   Continues to spike low grade temps, most likely source at this point is
   line infection.  On zosyn for concern for cholangitis given
   infected-appearing bile by ERCP.  Re-started Vanc [**9-28**] for suspected
   line infection, although vanc trough was therapeutic even after vanc
   was originally d/c
d. Concerning as wbc is growing without bands.
   - New lines placed
   - foley changed [**9-28**]
   - continue vanc and zosyn for now.  (Vanc Trought 22.2 this AM)
   - f/u culture data.
   - continue vasopressin.  levophed for MAPs < 65.  Wean down as
   tolerated
   - trend fever curve and WBC
   .
   # Acute renal failure:  BUN/Cr/K/PO4 up off CVVH.  Likely ATN highest
   on differential at this point. Started CVVH Monday afternoon [**9-25**];
   patient tolerating well.  D/c
d [**9-27**] overnight for line kinking and
   pustular drainage around line.  Re-started [**9-29**] as new IR lines
   placed, but only lasted 8 hours due to clogging filter.
   - Ensure technical difficulties are addressed and fixed so CVVH can
   continue
   - Renal following
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip
   stopped [**9-25**]
   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot
   take po
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to
   give maintenance dose through IV (200 mg/day) Currently received a
   total of XXX grams as of 0800 this AM.
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase.   LFTs trending down
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - trophic feeds started [**9-28**], advance as tolerated
   - TPN until tube feeds are at goal
   - Trend LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now given changes in TPN/tube feeds.
   - Trial of trophic tube feeds today and attempt to wean down insulin
   gtt
   - will calculate 24 hour insulin needs once on stable tube feeds and
   transition to long-acting regimen
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct  31 (from 52 at OSH when hemoconcentrated)
   but stable currently.  Guaiac + diarrhea + fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  Resolved. His platelets are up to 237 today.  Low
   suspicion for HIT, but HIT antibody sent, and subq heparin DCed
   yesterday.  [**Month (only) 8**] be secondary to Zosyn. (platelets 202 at outside
   hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.
   - No signs of active bleeding
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for procedure, will plan to advance tube feeds as
   tolerated with TPN bridge
   Glycemic Control:  insulin gtt

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to oliguric acute renal failure. The patient has hypoxic respiratory failure, likely due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and is being ventilated accordingly. He is also experiencing hypotension and septic shock, which is being managed with vasopressin and norepinephrine. The patient has a growing white blood cell count without bands, indicating a possible infection. He also has acute renal failure, likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and is undergoing CVVH. The patient was previously in atrial fibrillation but is now in sinus rhythm and receiving amiodarone. He has gallstone pancreatitis and had an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stent placement. The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, and he is being controlled on an insulin drip. He has anemia with a hemoglobin concentration of 31% and thrombocytopenia, which has resolved. The patient has multiple lines and is on various medications for prophylaxis. He is currently on a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) status with permission to intubate.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure and pancreatitis. He was admitted with gallstone pancreatitis, shock, and respiratory failure. Currently, the patient has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and persistent significant hypoxemia despite high PEEP and FiO2 requirements.

The patient is sedated and unable to provide history. He is on multiple medications including vasopressin, insulin, amiodarone, fentanyl, norepinephrine, and midazolam. The patient also has a central line, hemodialysis catheter, arterial line, and a new multilumen central line placed.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.9C, heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 100/53 mmHg to 152/72 mmHg, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on 90% FiO2.

The patient's physical examination reveals that he is intubated and sedated, with pupils that are constricted and minimally reactive. There is no wheezing appreciated in the pulmonary examination. Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure and pancreatitis. He was admitted with gallstone pancreatitis, shock, and respiratory failure. The patient now has Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) and persistent significant hypoxemia requiring high PEEP and FiO2. The patient is unable to provide history due to sedation.

24-hour events include the placement of a new hemodialysis (HD) and central line, as well as the initiation of continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH). The patient's condition has been unstable, with increased residuals and a filter clog in the CVVH circuit.

The patient is currently on multiple medications, including vasopressin, insulin, amiodarone, fentanyl, norepinephrine, and midazolam. He also receives pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis.

Vital signs show a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure of 100/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on ventilator support. The patient's weight is 135.4 kg, and he has a central venous pressure (CVP) of 19 mmHg. Fluid balance shows an input of 2,640 mL and output of 1,891 mL.

Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of HTN and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure currently
   on CVVH.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure/ARDS:  p/f ratio 158.  Ventilation per
   ARDS protocol with goal minimize TV and PEEP to keep plateau pressures
   low, goal < 40.  Has tolerated weaning to TV 370.  S/P IR procedure
   Friday likely derecruited a lot of lung as patient was initially on
   higher FiO2 and higher PEEP. Patient slowly improving, with FiO2 40%
   but still with high PEEP.
   - Continue to manage per ARDS net, goal PaO2 > 60, plateau pressures <
   40 for now given increased abdominal pressure and PEEP requirement.
   - Maintain FiO2 to 40% and decrease PEEP as tolerated to maintain paO2
   > 60
consider increasing FiO2 rather than increasing PEEP more.
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue CVVH as tolerated and increase rate of fluid loss as
   tolerated.
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  On vasopressin and levophed to maintain
   appropriate MAPs. Continues to spike low grade temps on CVVH. WBC
   improved. Unable to find source at this point. Lines changed [**9-29**].
   Was on Zosyn initially, but now changed to meropenem and cipro and vanc
   for broader coverage.  Other sources: VAP (unable to see on CXR in
   setting of ARDS); Sinusitis: but patient is being treated for this and
   has had no more discharge from his nares. Intra-abdominal is a
   possibility, but RUQ u/s negative for achalculous cholecystitis.
   Enzymes are all also trending down. C. diff possibility (previous was
   negative). Overall, unclear picture of source even though infection is
   likely given clinical picture.
   - if patient
s respiratory status improves consider CT of abdomen/chest
   and possibly sinuses.
   - continue vanc and meropenem (day 1: [**2169-9-29**]) for now.  (Vanc Trough
   20.1 in PM) Continue cipro (Day 1: [**2169-9-30**])
   - Vanc trough this AM before dosage: should dose all Abx with a CrCl of
   < 30 while on CVVH per Renal
   - f/u culture data.
   - Check C. diff today (negative x 1 so far)
   - Lactate normal
   - continue vasopressin.  levophed for MAPs < 65.  Wean down as
   tolerated
   - trend fever curve and WBC
   - foley changed [**9-28**]); New lines placed [**2169-9-29**]
   - If still unable to find source, consider LENI
s to rule out DVT.
   - Consider ID consult if no source of infection can be found on CT.
   - Perform sputum blood culture and sputum culture today as this should
   be done q 3 days in the ICU if no source is found.
   .
   # Acute renal failure:  BUN/Cr/K/PO4 up off CVVH.  Likely ATN highest
   on differential at this point. Started CVVH Monday afternoon [**9-25**];
   patient tolerating well.  D/c
d [**9-27**] overnight for line kinking and
   pustular drainage around line.  Re-started [**9-29**] as new IR lines
   placed, but only lasted 8 hours due to clogging filter. Re-started
   yesterday without any significant problems. Also given albumin with
   CVVH yesterday which appeared to be equivical.
   - Continue CVVH as tolerated and advance rate as tolerated. If patient
   becomes too hypotensive, change rate as net even rather than negative.
   - Renal following
   - Will discuss with renal the possibility of contrast in CT scan, if
   occurs tomorrow.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip
   stopped [**9-25**]
   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot
   take po
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to
   give maintenance dose through IV (200 mg/day) -  -
   - Currently received a total of XXX grams as of 0800 this AM.
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase.   LFTs trending down
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs if any
   - Surgery has signed off.
   - trophic feeds started [**9-28**], patient with significant residuals. Hold
   tube feeds for now in setting of decreased bowel sounds.
   - TPN for now
   - Trend LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Trophic tube feeds held due to high residuals. Hold for now.
   - Continue insulin gtt in setting of infection
   - Insulin in TPN.
   - will calculate 24 hour insulin needs if able to maintain stable tube
   feeds and transition to long-acting regimen
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct  29.9 (from 52 at OSH when
   hemoconcentrated) but stable currently.  Guaiac + diarrhea + fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  Resolved. His platelets are up to 237 today.  Low
   suspicion for HIT, and HIT antibody could not be sent as does not meet
   criteria for diagnosis, and subq heparin DCed [**2169-9-28**].  [**Month (only) 8**] be
   secondary to Zosyn. (platelets 202 at outside hospital admission)
   - Since plts are normalized,
   - Continue Heparin sub q.
   - Continue to trend.
   - No signs of active bleeding

   residuals.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma. He was transferred from another hospital due to worsening gallstone pancreatitis, which led to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure of 130/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 0 breaths per minute (mechanically ventilated), and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's general appearance is described as sedated and intubated, with no response to voice but responsive to suction.

Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and edema, small and equal pupils that are slightly reactive, supple neck, anteriorly improved breath sounds with air movement bilaterally, regular rhythm with soft heart sounds, distended and tympanic abdomen, and edematous extremities with 1+ pulses dorsalis pedis and 2+ radial pulses. Pus is noted in the femoral crease, and there is pustular drainage around the femoral line.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 29.9, decreased hemoglobin (Hct) at 28.1, decreased platelet count initially but now normalized at

   # Acute renal failure:  BUN/Cr/K/PO4 up off CVVH.  Likely ATN highest
   on differential at this point. Started CVVH Monday afternoon [**9-25**];
   patient tolerating well.  D/c
d [**9-27**] overnight for line kinking and
   pustular drainage around line.  Re-started [**9-29**] as new IR lines
   placed, but only lasted 8 hours due to clogging filter. Re-started
   yesterday without any significant problems. Also given albumin with
   CVVH yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH as tolerated and advance rate as tolerated
   - Ensure technical difficulties are addressed and fixed so CVVH can
   continue
   - Renal following
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip
   stopped [**9-25**]
   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot
   take po
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to
   give maintenance dose through IV (200 mg/day) Currently received a
   total of XXX grams as of 0800 this AM.
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase.   LFTs trending down
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - trophic feeds started [**9-28**], advance as tolerated
   - TPN until tube feeds are at goal
   - Trend LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now given changes in TPN/tube feeds.
   - Trial of trophic tube feeds today and attempt to wean down insulin
   gtt
   - will calculate 24 hour insulin needs once on stable tube feeds and
   transition to long-acting regimen
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct  31 (from 52 at OSH when hemoconcentrated)
   but stable currently.  Guaiac + diarrhea + fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  Resolved. His platelets are up to 237 today.  Low
   suspicion for HIT, and HIT antibody could not be sent as does not meet
   criteria for diagnosis, and subq heparin DCed [**2169-9-28**].  [**Month (only) 8**] be
   secondary to Zosyn. (platelets 202 at outside hospital admission)
   - Since plts are normalized, will re-start Heparin sub q.
   - Continue to trend.
   - No signs of active bleeding
   ICU Care

   residuals.

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH). 

The patient's current conditions include hypoxic respiratory failure (ARDS), hypotension/Septic Shock, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and gallstone pancreatitis. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure (ARDS): The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a goal PaO2 > 60 and plateau pressures < 40. Close monitoring and adjustment of FiO2 and PEEP as tolerated are necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation.

2. Hypotension/Septic Shock: The patient is on vasopressin and norepinephrine to maintain appropriate mean arterial pressures (MAPs). Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started, and the source of infection is still being sought. If the patient's respiratory status improves, a CT of the abdomen/chest may be considered.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is on CVVH with tolerable fluid loss. Technical difficulties with the CVVH should be addressed promptly. Renal function will be followed closely.

4. Atrial Fibr

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH). 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.6C, heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 124/55 to 153/65 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%. His heart rhythm is sinus rhythm. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 17.3 K/uL, elevated blood glucose levels, elevated liver enzymes, and abnormal kidney function tests. 

The patient has been diagnosed with several medical complications, including hypoxic respiratory failure/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), septic shock, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, gallstone pancreatitis, hyperglycemia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and possible Clostridium difficile infection. 

The patient's current treatment plan includes management of ARDS with low tidal volume ventilation and minimizing plateau pressures, continuous CVVH with increasing fluid loss as tolerated, vasopressor support to maintain appropriate mean arterial pressures, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and anticoagulation with heparin

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma. He was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis that progressed to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. The patient is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and mechanical ventilation due to ARDS.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient's oxygenation parameters (PaO2/FiO2 ratio) indicate severe hypoxemia, and he requires supplemental oxygen through mechanical ventilation. The goal is to maintain adequate oxygenation while minimizing ventilator-induced lung injury.

2. Septic shock: The patient's persistent fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest an ongoing infection. Despite changes in antibiotics, the source of infection has not been identified yet. Continued monitoring for signs of infection and source control are essential.

3. Acute renal failure: The patient's elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels indicate renal dysfunction. CVVH is being used to support renal function, and the rate of fluid loss should be adjusted based on the patient's hemodynamic status.

4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient is currently in sinus rhythm but has a history of atrial fibrillation. Close monitoring of heart rate and consideration for anticoagulation therapy may be necessary.

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma. He was transferred to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis, which led to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. The patient is currently on continuous venovenous hemodialysis (CVVHD).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient has a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 178, indicating severe hypoxemia. Ventilation per ARDS protocol is being followed to minimize tidal volume and plateau pressures. The goal is to maintain PaO2 above 60 and plateau pressures below 40.

2. Hypotension/Septic Shock: The patient requires vasopressin and levophed to maintain appropriate mean arterial pressures (MAPs). There are ongoing efforts to identify the source of infection, with broad-spectrum antibiotics being administered. Possible sources include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), sinusitis, intra-abdominal infection, or fungemia.

3. Acute renal failure: The patient has elevated BUN, creatinine, potassium, and phosphate levels. CVVH is being continued as tolerated, with a goal negative fluid balance of 2 liters. Albumin is also being given with CVVH.

4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is on amiodarone drips to maintain sinus rhythm. Diltiazem drip was stopped on

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma who was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis, which led to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. He is currently on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis) and has multiple complications, including ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), hypotension, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and gallstone pancreatitis.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Respiratory complications: The patient has ARDS, which can lead to further lung damage and respiratory failure. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation.
2. Infection-related complications: The patient has ongoing sepsis, and the source of infection is still unclear. There is a risk of developing central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), catheter-related urinary tract infection (CRUTI), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Kidney injury: The patient has acute renal failure, and there is a risk of worsening renal function or the development of chronic kidney disease.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient is experiencing hypotension and requires vasopressor support. There is a risk of myocardial infarction or cardiac dysfunction due to the stress on the cardiovascular system.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma. He was admitted to the ICU with worsening gallstone pancreatitis, leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. The patient is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 198, indicating severe hypoxemia. ARDS is likely, and the patient requires careful management to maintain adequate oxygenation while minimizing ventilator-induced lung injury. The goal is to keep plateau pressures below 40 cmH2O and ensure a PaO2 above 60 mmHg.

2. Septic Shock: The patient remains at risk for septic shock, despite being off vasopressors at the moment. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been initiated, including meropenem, ciprofloxacin, and vancomycin. It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's temperature, white blood cell count, and blood cultures to identify the source of infection.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to sepsis and hypoperfusion. CVVH has been started and needs to be continued to manage fluid and electrolyte balance, as well as acid-base disturbances. Daily assessments of renal function

- The plan is to wean FiO2 and decrease PEEP as tolerated while maintaining a PaO2 above 60.

2. Hypotension/Septic Shock:
- The patient was previously on vasopressin and levophed but is now off both.

- A line infection is suspected, and new lines have been placed.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, respiratory failure (ARDS), and oliguric renal failure. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH). The patient has been stable, but there are concerns about a possible fungal infection due to his immunocompromised state and the lack of clinical improvement.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has been managed according to ARDS protocol with ventilation settings aimed at maintaining a PaO2 > 60 and plateau pressures < 40. Weaning of FiO2 and PEEP will be done as tolerated.
2. Hypotension/Sep tic Shock: The patient was previously on vasopressor support, but is now off, with BPs being maintained. The source of infection is still unclear, and broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started. Further evaluation is needed to identify the source of infection.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is likely experiencing acute tubular necrosis (ATN). CVVH has been initiated and will continue with a goal negative 2-3 L/day. Renal function will be closely monitored.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is on amiodarone drips and is currently in sinus rhythm. The goal is to maintain a heart rate < 120 bpm to

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH). The patient has been improving slowly, with FiO2 at 50% and high PEEP requirement. He continues to be managed per ARDS protocol with a goal PaO2 > 60 and plateau pressures < 40. The patient is also on vasopressin and levophed to maintain appropriate mean arterial pressures (MAPs). He has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including meropenem, ciprofloxacin, and vancomycin, due to suspected or confirmed infection sources such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), sinusitis, intra-abdominal infection, and fungemia. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and sinuses is planned to further evaluate potential infection sources. The patient's renal function is improving, and CVVH is being continued as tolerated. He has a history of hyperglycemia, likely due to underlying type II diabetes, and is being managed with an insulin gtt. The patient also has anemia and thrombocytopenia, which have resolved with transfusions and medical management. His current medications include amiodarone, midazolam, fentanyl, calcium gluconate

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. The patient is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and mechanical ventilation.

The potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided are as follows:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient is experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure and ARDS. The ventilator settings need to be closely monitored to maintain adequate oxygenation and minimize ventilator-induced lung injury. There is a need to balance the tidal volume and PEEP to keep plateau pressures low.

2. Septic Shock: The patient has septic shock, and there is a concern about finding the source of infection. The patient's fever curve and white blood cell count should be trended. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started, but if no source is found, further evaluation for fungal coverage or trial off all antibiotics may be necessary.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has oliguric acute renal failure, and CVVH has been initiated. The patient tolerates the CVVH well, but there have been some issues with line kinking and clogging filters. The rate of CVVH should be advanced as tolerated, aiming for a negative fluid balance.

4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is in

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma. He was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis that progressed to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH).

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 198, indicating acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He is being managed per ARDS protocol with low tidal volume ventilation and low plateau pressures to minimize lung injury. The goal is to maintain a PaO2 > 60 while weaning FiO2 and decreasing PEEP as tolerated.

The patient is also experiencing hypotension due to septic shock. Pressors such as vasopressin and norepinephrine have been used to maintain blood pressure, but they have been discontinued for now. The source of infection remains unclear, and broad-spectrum antibiotics have been initiated. There is concern for fungal infection, and an ID consult has been requested for potential fungal coverage.

The patient has acute renal failure, likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). CVVH has been initiated and restarted multiple times due to line issues and filter clogging. The goal is to continue CVVHD as tolerated, aiming for a negative fluid balance of 2-3 liters.

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma. He was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis that led to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient's current condition includes hypoxic respiratory failure/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), hypotension/septic shock, acute renal failure, gallstone pancreatitis, hyperglycemia, atrial fibrillation, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

- Heart rate: 82 bpm
- Blood pressure: 107/44 mmHg
- Respiratory rate: 34 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 100%

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. He is currently on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis) and mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) and is being managed per ARDS protocol. The main goals are to maintain adequate oxygenation and minimize ventilator-induced lung injury.
2. Hypotension/Septic Shock: The patient continues to be hypotensive despite being off vasopressin and levophed. There is ongoing fever, and the source of infection is still unclear. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started, and a fungal infection is also suspected. Further investigations are needed to identify the source of infection.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has likely acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is receiving CVVH. The goal is to maintain negative fluid balance and advance the rate of CVVH as tolerated.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is in sinus rhythm but previously had atrial fibrillation. Amiodarone is being continued for now until the patient can tolerate oral medication.
5. Gallstone Pancreatitis: The patient underwent an ERCP procedure, and a CBD stent was placed.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH).

The patient has several ongoing medical issues that need to be addressed. Firstly, he is experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 198. The goal is to maintain a plateau pressure below 40 cmH2O and a PaO2 above 60. FiO2 and PEEP will be weaned as tolerated.

Secondly, the patient is hypotensive/septic shock. He is afebrile for 24 hours and is currently on meropenem, ciprofloxacin, and vancomycin. Micafungin has been added for presumed fungemia. The source of infection has not yet been identified, and other potential etiologies include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), sinusitis, intra-abdominal infection, or ongoing pancreatitis. Further investigations, such as a CT scan, are planned to identify the source of infection.

Thirdly, the patient has acute renal failure, likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). CVVH has been started and will be continued as tolerated, with

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma who was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH). The patient's condition is still unstable with ongoing hypotension and fever. Despite being afebrile for 24 hours, the source of infection remains unclear, and he has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and antifungal medications. Other potential causes of fever are being investigated.

Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 198 and requires mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume and appropriate PEEP levels to maintain plateau pressures below 40. FiO2 and PEEP will be weaned as tolerated.
2. Hypotension/Septic Shock: Despite being afebrile for 24 hours, the patient remains hypotensive and requires vasopressors. Broad-spectrum antibiotics, including meropenem, ciprofloxacin, and vancomycin, have been started, along with antifungal coverage due to suspicion of fungemia. The source of infection is still unclear.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is receiving CVVH. The filter has been changed, and

He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to oliguric acute renal failure. 3. Gallstone pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen or lead to complications such as pancreatic pseudocyst or abscess formation.

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred from another hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient's low PaO2/FiO2 ratio indicates the need for continued monitoring and management of ARDS. The plan includes weaning off mechanical ventilation and providing supplemental oxygen as needed.

2. Sepsis: The patient has been treated for presumed sepsis with broad-spectrum antibiotics. The source of infection remains unclear, and further investigation is needed to identify the causative organism. Fungemia is also a possibility, and antifungal coverage has been initiated.

3. Acute renal failure: The patient likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) secondary to sepsis and hypotension. CVVH has been started, and the goal is to maintain a negative fluid balance. Renal function should continue to be monitored closely.

4. Gallstone pancreatitis: The patient underwent an ERCP procedure with CBD stent placement. His lipase and amylase levels are improving, indicating a response to the intervention. Further evaluation of biliary ducts and consideration of alternative sources for elevated alkaline phosphatase should be done.

5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's high blood sugar levels suggest undiagnosed diabetes, which needs to be managed with insulin therapy. Trophic tube feeds have been started, and close monitoring of blood glucose levels is essential.

6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient is currently in sinus rhythm but has a history of atrial fibrillation. Maintenance dosing of amiodarone should be considered once the loading dose is completed.

7. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's hematocrit and platelet counts are stable, indicating that these conditions have resolved. However, ongoing monitoring and appropriate interventions should be considered if there are any changes.

8. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Prophylactic measures such as heparin and pneumatic boots should be continued to prevent DVT.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of multiple organ systems, including respiratory, renal, endocrine, and cardiovascular functions.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to oliguric acute renal failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable with a blood pressure of 123/50 mmHg, heart rate of 84 bpm, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His lungs are clear, but he is still on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 370 mL, respiratory system compliance of 46.3 mL/cmH2O, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 20 cmH2O. The patient's glucose levels have been in the 200s, and he has been on an insulin drip to control his blood sugar.

The patient has a history of anemia but is currently stable with a hematocrit level of 25.2%. He also has thrombocytopenia, which has resolved, and his platelet count is now normal. He is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers, so he is receiving prophylactic heparin and a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), respectively.

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH).

The patient's current condition includes hypoxic respiratory failure/ARDS with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 270. He is being ventilated according to ARDS protocol with a tidal volume (TV) of 370 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 20 cmH2O. His lung fields are largely clear on CT and chest X-ray, so he may not need ARDS protocol ventilation. The plan is to decrease PEEP to 18 cmH2O and switch to pressure support if tolerated.

The patient also has hypotension/Septic Shock, which has improved, and he is now off pressors. He has had no fever for 48 hours, and his WBC count is stable. He is being treated with meropenem, ciprofloxacin, and vancomycin, and micafungin has been added for presumed fungemia. Other potential sources of infection, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), sinusitis, and intra-abdominal infection, are being addressed.

The patient's gallstone pancreatitis is improving, with CBD stenting placed by ERCP fellow.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure. The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has a low oxygenation index (p/f ratio 198) and is being managed according to ARDS protocol. The goal is to maintain a PaO2 > 60, plateau pressures < 40, and wean FiO2 and PEEP as tolerated.
2. Hypotension/Septic Shock: Despite being afebrile for 24 hours, the patient remains hypotensive and requires pressors. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started, and a fungal infection is suspected, so antifungal coverage has been added. The source of infection is still unclear.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is receiving CVVH. The goal is to advance the rate of CVVH and aim for negative fluid balance of -2 to -3 L.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from another hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to oliguric acute renal failure. 

The patient's respiratory status has improved, and lung fields are clear on CT and chest X-ray. The patient is now off ARDS ventilation and is tolerating pressure support well. The plan is to continue weaning the patient off sedation and allow spontaneous breathing.

The patient's blood sugar levels are being controlled with insulin in the total parenteral nutrition (TPN), as he likely had underlying type II diabetes. His renal function is being monitored closely, and CVVH is being continued as tolerated, with the goal of achieving negative fluid balance.

The patient's skin condition is being monitored due to bullous lesions on the thigh and a rash on the flank and extremities. These lesions are likely stasis dermatitis and less likely drug rashes. No therapy is planned at this time.

The patient's gastrointestinal function is being assessed, and he is being advanced to tube feeds while decreasing TPN. 

The patient's atrial fibrillation is being managed with amiodarone, and the goal is to maintain his heart rate below 120 beats per minute to improve cardiac output and perfusion.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH). The patient has multiple complications including hypoxic respiratory failure/ARDS, hypotension/septic shock, hyperglycemia, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has a low PaO2/FiO2 ratio indicating severe hypoxemia. There is a risk of further deterioration in lung function and the need for increased ventilatory support.
2. Hypotension/Sep tic Shock: Despite being afebrile for 48 hours, the patient's WBC count is stable, and he is on broad-spectrum antibiotics, there is still a risk of recurrent septic shock. Monitoring for signs of hypotension and organ dysfunction is crucial.
3. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, and he has a history of type II diabetes. It is essential to maintain tight glycemic control to prevent complications such as infections and poor wound healing.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he is dependent on CVVH. There is a risk of further deterioration in renal function

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH).

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.8C, heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure of 139/55 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on supplemental oxygen. His general appearance is sedated and intubated, with sclera icteric and scleral edema improved. Pupils are small and equal, mildly reactive, and there is a endotracheal tube in place.

His neck is supple, with jugular venous distention (JVD) difficult to assess due to neck edema. Lungs are clear bilaterally, with normal air movement. Heart sounds are regular, with a normal S1/S2, but difficult to appreciate for murmurs due to the sedation. Abdomen shows bowel sounds, decreased distension and tympanicity, some dullness to percussion at flanks and inferiorly, slightly improved from yesterday. Genitourinary examination reveals an erythematous, edematous scrotum, penis with scab/blister area at the base. Extremities

   dyssynchrony. Having regular bowel movements now after starting
   narcan/erythro. Having thick tan secretions. Remains on TPN.

   level), insulin drip, erythro, [**Last Name (un) 350**], narcan PO q6h, famotidine in TPN,
   TF were at goal but had residuals and emesis this AM.
   Impression/Plan

   bolus. For sepsis, pancreatitis, necrotic pancreatitis, will continue

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred from another hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to oliguric acute renal failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Hypoxic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient is improving and able to be weaned from the ventilator. ABGs have been stable with decreases in PS. Plan for a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) later this afternoon with 0 PEEP and possible extubation today or tomorrow morning depending on how he tolerates weaning of his PEEP.
- Hypotension/septic shock: The patient is afebrile for 72 hours, with low-grade temperatures. WBC slightly increased from 14 to 16. Currently on meropenem, vanc, and micafungin. Micafungin was added for presumed fungemia. Recent CT showed necrotic pancreas but with no other source of infection, no abscess formation. Has been off pressors. Plan to start to peel off antibiotics as per ID as long as he does not show any further signs of infection.
- Hyperglycemia: The patient's sugars were in the 500's at the OSH, likely underlying type II diabetes. Controlled on an insulin gtt + insulin in TPN, which is increased today.
- Skin: Some bullous lesions on the left anterior/superior thigh where tape was previously placed. Erythematous blanching rash on the left flank, right lower extremity, and right upper extremity. Per derm, likely stasis dermatitis. Less likely drug rash without maculopapular pattern and no eosinophilia. Exam is improving.
- FEN/GI: The patient has more consistent bowel movements today, but with increased residuals today. Spoke with nutrition and changed to a more elemental tube feed that he may tolerate better, but he may end up needing a post pyloric feeding tube.
- Acute renal failure: Likely ATN. Started CVVH on 9/25. D/c on 9/27 for line kinking and pustular drainage around line. Re-started on 9/29 after new IR lines placed, but only lasted 8 hours due to clogging filter. Re-started on 9/30 without any significant problems.
- Gallstone pancreatitis: CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow. Improving lipase and amylase. LFTs trending down. Alk phos stable, elevated likely due to cholestasis (atonic GB) + TPN.
- Atrial fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Patient will reach loading dose this afternoon, will d/c amio as patient has remained in SR.
- Anemia: HCT stable.
- Thrombocytopenia: Resolved.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
3. Stress ulcer bleeding
4. Renal failure
5. Hyperglycemia
6. Infection (due to immunosuppression)
7. Skin breakdown and pressure ulcers
8. Malnutrition
9. Atrial fibrillation

Please note that this summary is based on the provided progress note and does not cover all possible complications that may occur.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) and is being weaned off the ventilator.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has been weaned from the ventilator and is currently on PS [7-22]. ABG results have been stable, and the plan is to further decrease PEEP and possibly extubate him today or tomorrow morning.

2. Hypotension/Septic Shock: The patient is afebrile for 72 hours, with low-grade temperatures. He is on meropenem, vancomycin, and micafungin. Micafungin was added for presumed fungemia. Recent CT showed necrotic pancreas but no other source of infection or abscess formation. He is currently off pressors.

3. Hyperglycemia: The patient likely had underlying type II diabetes, as evidenced by sugars in the 500's at the outside hospital. His blood sugars are now in the 250's, and he is being controlled on an insulin gtt + insulin in TPN, now at 120 units. The plan is to increase the insulin in TPN to 140 units and restart the insulin drip today.

4. Skin: The patient has bullous lesions on his left anterior/superior thigh where tape was previously placed. He also has an erythematous blanching rash on his left flank and right lower extremity. These may be due to stasis dermatitis or drug rash, but no therapy is currently being given.

5. FEN/GI: The patient has had bowel movements and docusate has been held. He is on trophic tube feeds at 10 cc/hr and has active bowel sounds. The plan is to advance tube feeds per nutrition recommendations while decreasing TPN.

6. Acute Renal Failure: The patient likely has acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and started CVVH on [9-25]. He had a line kinking and pustular drainage around the line, which resulted in discontinuation of CVVH. New IR lines were placed, and CVVH was restarted on [9-29]. However, it only lasted 8 hours due to a clogged filter. CVVH was restarted again on [9-30] without any significant problems.

7. Gallstone Pancreatitis: The patient had a CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow. His lipase and amylase levels are improving, and his liver function tests (LFTs) are trending down.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma, who was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient is currently on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) and mechanical ventilation. He is being treated for suspected sepsis with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including meropenem, vancomycin, and micafungin. The patient's recent laboratory results show stable white blood cell count, but elevated lactate levels. His blood glucose levels have been in the 500's, suggesting possible undiagnosed diabetes. The patient has also been experiencing hyperglycemia and has been managed with an insulin drip. The patient's skin condition includes bullous lesions on the thigh and a rash on the flank and lower extremities, which may be due to stasis dermatitis or medication reaction. The patient's gastrointestinal function is being supported with total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and trophic tube feeds. He is also receiving CVVH for acute renal failure, likely caused by acute tubular necrosis (ATN). The patient's cardiac status includes atrial fibrillation, for which he is receiving amiodarone. His anemia and thrombocytopenia have resolved. The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, indicating do not resuscitate/do not intubate.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma. He was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure. 

The patient has been on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) due to acute renal failure. His blood cultures showed no signs of infection, so micafungin was discontinued. The patient's antibiotics will be tapered off as per the Infectious Disease (ID) recommendation, monitoring for any signs of infection such as leukocytosis or fever. 

The patient's respiratory status has improved significantly, and he is now able to be weaned from the ventilator. He is currently on PSV (pressure support ventilation) mode and has done well. The plan is to further wean the ventilator by decreasing PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) and possibly extubate him today or tomorrow morning, depending on how he tolerates the weaning process.

The patient's skin condition is improving, with resolving bullous lesions and erythematous blanching rash on the flank. These were initially suspected to be related to a fungal infection, but a CT scan and B-glucan test were negative, and the dermatologist declined to perform a biopsy. 

The patient's hyperglycemia is being managed with an insulin gtt + insulin in T

- The patient's atrial fibrillation has resolved, and he will be discharged from amiodarone.

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma. He was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis that led to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to oliguric acute renal failure.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.1C (100.6F), heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure of 133/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient is sedated and intubated, with an endotracheal tube in place. He is receiving mechanical ventilation in the assist-control mode with a tidal volume of 351 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%, and respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 59.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 256 K/uL, elevated lactate levels at 1.0 mmol/L, and decreased platelet count at 256 platelets/uL. Blood cultures have been negative so far. The patient's blood glucose levels are in the 500's, indicating hyperglycemia.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of gallstone pancreatitis who underwent ERCP with CBD stenting. The patient's course has been complicated by hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute renal failure (ARF), for which he is currently oliguric on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH).

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.5 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 96 beats per minute, blood pressure of 183/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 37 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92% on supplemental oxygen. He is sedated and not following commands.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated platelet count, increased creatinine, and altered liver function tests. Imaging reveals bilateral pleural effusions and smaller lung volumes.

The patient's medical conditions include acute respiratory failure, sepsis, necrotic pancreatitis, renal failure, ileus/nutrition, anemia, and DNR status. The plan is to continue with vancomycin and discontinue meropenem. CVVH will be continued, and the patient's ileus and nutrition will be managed accordingly. Close monitoring of glycemic control and hemoglobin levels is recommended.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, infection due to prolonged sedation and immobility, further deterioration of renal function

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma. He was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis, which led to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. Currently, he is on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to oliguric acute renal failure.

The patient has shown improvements in his respiratory status, with stable ABGs and decreases in positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP). The plan is to perform a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) later today with propofol weaned off, and possible extubation today or tomorrow morning depending on how he tolerates weaning of his PEEP.

The patient's hypotension and septic shock are being managed with appropriate antibiotic therapy. The recent CT scan showed necrotic pancreas but no other source of infection or abscess formation. The patient is expected to be stable off pressors.

The patient's hyperglycemia is controlled on insulin in total parenteral nutrition (TPN), and the insulin gtt is to be discontinued. The skin findings include bullous lesions and an erythematous blanching rash, which are likely due to stasis dermatitis.

Regarding the gastrointestinal system, the patient has more consistent bowel movements today, and new tube feeds with less lipids are being tried to improve residuals. Erythromycin was discontinued yesterday as it did not seem to be helping. The possibility of

   - check residuals Q 4 hrs
   - d/c TPN once tolerating Tube Feeds, pt gets 160u insulin in TPN so
   expect hyperglycemia on TF
   - continue bowel regimen with PR dulcolax, POG colace, senna as prn
   # Acute renal failure:  likely ATN. Started CVVH [**9-25**].  D/c
d [**9-27**]
   for line kinking and pustular drainage around line.  Re-started [**9-29**]
   after new IR lines placed, but only lasted 8 hours due to clogging
   filter. Re-started [**9-30**] without any significant problems.   [**Name (NI) 6**] had
   intermittent filter clogging problems w CVVH including last night
   - CVVH again today, then switch to HD tomorrow
   - Patient now at a lower weight than on admission, but he presented
   from outside hospital already 8-10L up; Renal team feels his dry weight
   is close to 100 to 102 kg.
   - Continue CVVHD today -- Goal negative -2 L today
   - Renal following, appreciate recs
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase.   LFTs stable, normalized.  Alk phos still elevated
   but stable, and T Bili trending down.  Alk phos elevated likely due to
   cholestasis (atonic GB) + TPN.
   - Trend LFTs and pancreatic enzymes QOD
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient in sinus rhythm w rate in 90s.  Reached
   loading dose on [**10-6**], so amio gtt was DCed, but loading dose should
   stay in his system for a while.
   - cont to monitor and may start home calcium channel blocker
   - increase metoprolol to 25 mg TID
   .
   # Anemia: HCT drop to 23 this AM, but repeat is 26, so did not
   transfuse.  Will need to cont to monitor.
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and asthma. He was transferred from another hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis that led to septic shock and hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to oliguric acute renal failure.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.5 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 78 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 133/57 mmHg to 195/69 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%.

The patient's mental status is a barrier to extubation, and the healthcare provider needs to be contacted regarding reintubation if extubation fails. The patient's lungs are clear to auscultation, and he is receiving supplemental oxygen through an endotracheal tube on CPAP/PSV+ApnVol mode.

The patient's abdomen is soft, distended, and tympanic to percussion with hypoactive bowel sounds. He has right and left lower extremity edema, but no cyanosis or clubbing. Neurologically, the patient is not attentive, does not follow simple commands, and responds inadequately.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 9.9 thousand/mm3, elevated creatinine levels, and hyperglycemia with blood glucose levels in the 500's. The patient's platelet count is 284 thousand/mm3, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 47 mg/dL.

The patient's current plan involves weaning off propofol and starting a spontaneous breathing trial in the morning. The CVVH machine clotted again, so it will be held off tonight, and the patient may switch to hemodialysis (HD) tomorrow. The patient's fluid balance shows an intake of 6,393 mL and output of 7,965 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 1,572 mL.

Potential medical complications that can arise include reintubation if the patient fails extubation, ongoing management of acute renal failure, and monitoring for any signs of infection or sepsis.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of gallstone pancreatitis and sepsis. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated in the ICU due to respiratory failure. His primary obstacle to extubation is altered mental status. The patient is tolerating intermittent mandatory ventilation (IMV) mode and has shown some improvement. 

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure attributed to sepsis and altered mental status. Monitoring and support with mechanical ventilation are ongoing.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has improved but should be closely monitored to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.
3. Sepsis: Although improved, the patient should be monitored for any signs of sepsis recurrence. Antibiotics should be completed as prescribed.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is attributed to medications. Close monitoring is necessary, and adjustments to medication doses may be required.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels should be monitored, and efforts should be made to maintain them below 150 mg/dL.
6. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). He is tolerating continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD) and may require further hemodialysis.
7. Pancreatitis: The patient has acute pancreatitis

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of gallstone pancreatitis and sepsis. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated in the ICU due to respiratory failure. The primary obstacle to extubation remains altered mental status. The patient is tolerating intermittent mandatory ventilation (IMS) mode and has shown good progress. 

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: Attributed to sepsis and altered mental status. The patient's underlying asthma is also a contributing factor. The plan is to continue moving towards extubation trials as mental status improves.
2. Hypotension: Improved but needs monitoring to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 60 mmHg.
3. Sepsis: Improved and currently being treated with antimicrobials. Monitoring is ongoing.
4. Altered Mental Status: Attributed to medications. Will be monitored for improvement.
5. Hyperglycemia: Glucose levels need to be monitored and maintained below 150 mg/dL.
6. Acute Renal Failure: Attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Tolerating continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), considering hemodialysis.
7. Pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis caused by gallstones. The patient underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) stent placement. Monitoring includes examining for complications, liver function tests

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was admitted to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure. The patient is currently on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) and has been stable off pressors.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided include:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's mental status is not ready for extubation, and there is a concern about reintubation if he fails extubation.

2. Septic/distributive shock: Although the patient is currently stable off pressors, there is a need to monitor closely for any signs of infection or new focus of infection. The patient's white blood cell count is trending down, and no culture growth has been observed so far. A recent CT scan showed necrotic pancreas but no other source of infection or abscess formation.

3. Hyperglycemia: The patient has high fasting blood sugar levels, indicating likely underlying type II diabetes. Insulin therapy will be initiated to control blood glucose levels.

4. Skin issues: The patient has bullous lesions on the left anterior/superior thigh where tape was previously placed, and an erythematous blanching rash on the left flank, right lower extremity, and right upper extremity. These rashes may be due to stasis dermatitis or

- The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma.

- The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) and has had multiple lines placed.
- He has low-grade fever, which could indicate inflammation from a necrotic pancreas or a new source of infection.
- The patient has been extubated but may require reintubation if he fails to wean off mechanical ventilation.
- His mental status remains poor, and he is not yet ready for extubation.
- He has hyperglycemia due to poorly functioning pancreas and stenotic splenic vein.
- The patient has bullous lesions on his thigh and a rash on his flank, which may be stasis dermatitis or drug rash.
- He has acute renal failure likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and CVVH has been restarted after initial issues with line kinking and clogging.
- The patient's gallstone pancreatitis is improving with the placement of a CBD stent.
- He had atrial fibrillation but is now in sinus rhythm.
- Anemia is present and needs

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of gallstone pancreatitis and sepsis, complicated by acute renal failure and persistent altered mental status. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated. He is somewhat more awake and responding to questions with eye-blinking. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.9C (100.2F), heart rate of 83 bpm, blood pressure of 131/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated blood glucose levels, elevated lactate levels, and other abnormalities in electrolytes and kidney function.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is attributed to sepsis, altered mental status, and volume resuscitation. The underlying asthma should also be considered. The plan is to continue moving towards extubation trial as mental status improves.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has improved but should be monitored, and blood pressure should be maintained at a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 60 mmHg.

3. Sepsis: Although the patient's sepsis has improved, it should continue to be monitored. Antimicrobials have been completed, and cultures have been submitted. If possible, lines should be decannulated.

4. Fever
